original_title: Sri Lanka shares dip as banking and financial sectors face profit-taking
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares were down at the close on Monday, mainly dragged down by the banking and financial sectors as profit-taking continued after a run on green for seven sessions over the assurance of the conclusion of the International Monetary Fund loan facility, brokers said.
The main All Share Price Index (ASPI) closed down 1.21 percent, or 115.92 points, at 9,491.84.
“Banking sector saw the highest profit-taking, which pushed the index down,” an analyst said.
“Investors who were overwhelmed by the IMF news have pushed for selling on profit.”
Analysts said similar activity can be seen in the retail sector as well.

After getting China’s assurance on debt restructuring and sending the Letter of Intent for the IMF Executive Board approval, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said on Tuesday that it is expected to receive the Executive Board approval in the third or fourth week of March.

Speculations on price decrease in fuel in the future, after the comments of Minister Susil Premajanatha last week, have caused investors to start pulling out from the Lanka IOC shares, while the fall in freight charges affected the Expolanka shares, analysts said.
The market saw a net foreign inflow of 25.4 million rupees. So far in 2023, the market has recorded a total net foreign inflow of 3.04 billion rupees.
The most liquid index, S&P SL20, closed 1.00 percent, or 28.30 points, down at 2,794.84.
The market saw a turnover of 2.1 billion rupees on Monday, slightly higher than this year’s daily average of 1.9 billion rupees.
The top losers were Hatton National Bank, Lanka IOC, and Central Finance Company. (Colombo/Mar 13/2023)
